user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_DeleteAllObjects:
```c
void OS_DeleteAllObjects(void)
{
    uint32 ObjectCount;
    uint32 TryCount;

    /*
     * Note - this is done in a loop because some objects depend on other objects
     * and you will not be able to delete the object until the ref count becomes zero.
     */
    TryCount = 0;
    while (true)
    {
        ObjectCount = 0;
        ++TryCount;

        /* Delete timers and tasks first, as they could be actively using other object types  */
        OS_ForEachObjectOfType(OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMECB, OS_OBJECT_CREATOR_ANY, OS_CleanUpObject, &ObjectCount);
        OS_ForEachObjectOfType(OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMEBASE, OS_OBJECT_CREATOR_ANY, OS_CleanUpObject, &ObjectCount);
        OS_ForEachObjectOfType(OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TASK, OS_OBJECT_CREATOR_ANY, OS_CleanUpObject, &ObjectCount);

        /* Then try to delete all other remaining objects of any type */
        OS_ForEachObject(OS_OBJECT_CREATOR_ANY, OS_CleanUpObject, &ObjectCount);

        if (ObjectCount == 0 || TryCount > 4)
        {
            break;
        }
        OS_TaskDelay(5);
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_DeleteAllObjects:
void OS_ForEachObjectOfType(osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t creator_id, OS_ArgCallback_t callback_ptr,
                            void *callback_arg)
{
    OS_object_iter_t    iter;
    OS_creator_filter_t filter;

    filter.creator_id    = creator_id;
    filter.user_callback = callback_ptr;
    filter.user_arg      = callback_arg;

    if (OS_ObjectIdIteratorInit(OS_ForEachFilterCreator, &filter, idtype, &iter) == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        while (OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext(&iter))
        {
            OS_ObjectIdIteratorProcessEntry(&iter, OS_ForEachDoCallback);
        }

        OS_ObjectIdIteratorDestroy(&iter);
    }
}
...
void OS_ForEachObject(osal_id_t creator_id, OS_ArgCallback_t callback_ptr, void *callback_arg)
{
    osal_objtype_t idtype;

    for (idtype = 0; idtype < OS_OBJECT_TYPE_USER; ++idtype)
    {
        OS_ForEachObjectOfType(idtype, creator_id, callback_ptr, callback_arg);
    }
}
...
int32 OS_TaskDelay(uint32 millisecond)
{
    /* just call the implementation */
    return OS_TaskDelay_Impl(millisecond);
}
...
void OS_CleanUpObject(osal_id_t object_id, void *arg)
{
    uint32 *ObjectCount;

    ObjectCount = (uint32 *)arg;
    ++(*ObjectCount);
    switch (OS_IdentifyObject(object_id))
    {
        case OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TASK:
            OS_TaskDelete(object_id);
            break;
        case OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_QUEUE:
            OS_QueueDelete(object_id);
            break;
        case OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_BINSEM:
            OS_BinSemDelete(object_id);
            break;
        case OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_COUNTSEM:
            OS_CountSemDelete(object_id);
            break;
        case OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_MUTEX:
            OS_MutSemDelete(object_id);
            break;
        case OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_MODULE:
            OS_ModuleUnload(object_id);
            break;
        case OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMEBASE:
            OS_TimeBaseDelete(object_id);
            break;
        case OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMECB:
            OS_TimerDelete(object_id);
            break;
        case OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_STREAM:
            OS_close(object_id);
            break;
        case OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_DIR:
            OS_DirectoryClose(object_id);
            break;
        case OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_CONDVAR:
            OS_CondVarDelete(object_id);
            break;
        default:
            break;
    }
}
...
#define OS_OBJECT_CREATOR_ANY OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMECB 0x09
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMEBASE 0x08
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TASK 0x01
...
void UT_ExecuteBasicHandler(UT_EntryKey_t FuncKey, const char *FunctionName, UT_HandlerFunc_t DefaultHandler)
{
    /* Check if the test case registered a hook, and use the default if not */
    if (UT_GetStubEntry(FuncKey, UT_ENTRYTYPE_FINAL_HANDLER) == NULL && DefaultHandler != NULL)
    {
        UT_SetHandlerFunction(FuncKey, DefaultHandler, NULL);
    }

    UT_DefaultStubImpl(FunctionName, FuncKey, 0, NULL);
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No function in the supplied code modifies any of its own parameters (which would violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8). Specific reasons per fragment:

- OS_DeleteAllObjects(void): Has no parameters, so the rule does not apply.

- OS_ForEachObjectOfType(osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t creator_id, OS_ArgCallback_t callback_ptr, void *callback_arg): All parameter values are copied into a local 'filter' structure; there is no assignment to the parameter variables themselves. No pointer parameter is reassigned; only the local copy filter.user_arg receives callback_arg.

- OS_ForEachObject(osal_id_t creator_id, OS_ArgCallback_t callback_ptr, void *callback_arg): The function iterates using a local variable 'idtype' and passes the incoming parameters unchanged to OS_ForEachObjectOfType. There is no modification of creator_id, callback_ptr, or callback_arg.

- OS_TaskDelay(uint32 millisecond): Simply forwards the parameter to OS_TaskDelay_Impl(millisecond) without modifying the parameter variable.

- OS_CleanUpObject(osal_id_t object_id, void *arg): The pointer parameter 'arg' is cast to a uint32* and the pointed-to object is incremented (++(*ObjectCount)). Modifying the object referred to by a pointer parameter is allowed by the rule; importantly, the pointer parameter 'arg' itself is not reassigned or modified. The value parameter object_id is not changed; it is passed to other functions but not assigned to.

- UT_ExecuteBasicHandler(UT_EntryKey_t FuncKey, const char *FunctionName, UT_HandlerFunc_t DefaultHandler): Parameters are inspected and passed to other functions; none of the parameter variables are modified. FunctionName is a const char* and is not altered.

No occurrences of parameter reassignment (for example param = ..., ++param, param++, or reassigning pointer parameters) are present in the provided code. Therefore there are no code fragments that need investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8.
